case_title: Shri Krishna Pharmaceuticals Limited vs UOI
complaint_summary: The petitioner challenges the communication dated 2.9.2002 issued by the Ministry of Finance, Department of Revenue, rejecting exemption for two consignments under the Advance License Scheme despite prior clarifications and court orders.
investigation_summary: The petitioner imported Acetic Anhydride under the Advance License Scheme, which exempts customs duty for raw materials used in exported goods. Notifications and clarifications were issued, but exemptions were inconsistently applied, leading to demand notices and appeals.
judgment_summary: The court held that the petitioner is entitled to exemptions for all three consignments under the Advance License Scheme. It directed the respondents to extend exemptions for consignments under Bill of Entry 293 and 305 within 10 weeks, citing failure to comply with prior court directives.
Decision_or_verdict: Writ petition allowed; exemptions directed to be extended for consignments under Bill of Entry 293 and 305.
legal_arguments: Legitimate expectation and promissory estoppel invoked by petitioner.
Respondents argued actions were justified under Section 25 of the Customs Act.
key_issues: Non-extension of exemptions under Advance License Scheme.
Failure to comply with prior court directives.
Validity of communication dated 2.9.2002 rejecting exemption for consignments.

legal_terms.Advance License Scheme: A scheme allowing duty-free imports of raw materials used in exported goods.
legal_terms.Promissory Estoppel: A legal principle preventing a party from going back on a promise.

words_and_phrases.Legitimate Expectation: The belief that a party will receive benefits based on established practices or promises.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the withdrawal and subsequent clarification of exemptions under the Advance License Scheme for imported Acetic Anhydride. The court found the respondents failed to comply with prior directives and granted relief to the petitioner, ensuring exemptions for all consignments.

notifications.effect: Clarification that Advance License transactions are unaffected

consignments.status: Initially detained, later cleared without customs duty

appeals.result: Appeals withdrawn with liberty to approach High Court

writ_petitions.result: Division Bench directed respondents to pass detailed orders
Division Bench directed respondents to pass detailed orders
Division Bench directed respondents to pass detailed orders

petitioner: Exemption under Advance License Scheme was withdrawn by Notification No. 183/93-Cus.
Clarification issued by Notification No. 105/94-Cus reinstated exemption.
Respondents failed to provide reasons for rejecting exemption for consignments 1 and 2.
respondent: Actions justified under Section 25 of the Customs Act.
Policy supports non-clearance of consignments 1 and 2.

key_findings: Respondents failed to comply with earlier High Court directions to pass detailed orders.
Petitioner entitled to exemption under Advance License Scheme for all three consignments.
orders: Respondents directed to extend exemptions for consignments under Bill of Entry 293 (dated 1993-12-03) and 305 (dated 1993-12-18).
Exercise to be completed within 10 weeks.
